item.title: Trump Says Golden Dome Will Be Operational in Three Years
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed that a “Golden Dome” missile-defense shield would be “fully operational” by the end of his term, and offer the US protection from an array of threats — even though some of the technology remains unproven.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY

item.title: Mexico City Mayor’s Aides Shot Dead by Attackers on Motorbikes
item.description: Two senior aides to Mexico City Mayor Clara Brugada were shot dead Tuesday in the highest-profile political violence to strike the Latin American metropolis since cartel gunmen ambushed the capital’s former police chief five years ago.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Millan, Andrea Navarro

media:content.media:description: Forensic investigators work at the crime scene of the killing of Jose Munoz and Ximena Guzman in Mexico City on May 20, 2025.

item.title: FAA Cuts Newark Flights After Air Traffic Control Issues
item.description: US aviation safety regulators will allow fewer flights at Newark airport after technology outages and a staffing crunch fueled a surge in delays and cancellations in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille, Mary Schlangenstein

media:content.media:description: A FAA Air Traffic Control tower and the Newark Liberty International Airport Marriott at Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) in Newark, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Air traffic controllers guiding planes bound for Newark Liberty International Airport lost radar and radio communication for more than a minute early last week before flights at the key hub were snarled for days, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: South Africa’s Budget Gets Third Reboot With Credibility on Line
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana’s third attempt to deliver a budget represents his sternest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, center, speaks to the press after presenting the revised 2025 Budget at the National Assembly in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Godongwana and his National Treasury officials were sent back to the drawing board last month after his revenue and spending plan failed to get buy-in from parties.

item.title: US Clears Way for Tariffs on $13 Billion of Solar Imports
item.description: US duties on solar equipment from four Southeast Asian countries are set to take effect following a government agency’s conclusion the imports harm domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Mark Chediak, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: A worker handles photovoltaic cells at Irex Energy JSC's manufacturing facility in Vung Tau, Vietnam, on Monday, July 15, 2019. After U.S. President Donald Trump slapped higher tariffs on China, production in neighboring Vietnam went into overdrive. Chinese manufacturers, who face a 55% U.S. tariff on their goods, relocated some production to Vietnam, while local businesses saw a jump in orders. In June alone, U.S. imports of solar cells from Vietnam surged 656% from a year ago.

item.title: UK Sanctions British Accountant for Alleged Russia Ship Deals
item.description: The UK sanctioned an English accountant for allegedly helping Russia expand the fleet of tankers it uses to covertly ship crude around the globe.
item.dc:creator: Emma Sanchez

media:content.media:description: Oil tanker. Photographer: Marcelo del Pozo/Bloomberg

item.title: ‘Original Sin’ Lays Out How Biden’s Decline Was Hidden by Family, Staff
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, Bloomberg Businessweek national correspondent Joshua Green looks at the revelations in a new book about how former President Joe Biden’s family and staff hid his decline while in office. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Green

media:content.media:description: US President Joe Biden walks to the Rose Garden to deliver remarks at the White House on November 26, 2024 in Washington, DC. Photographer: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images North America

item.title: Sanctions Risk Pushing Russia Away From Talks, Rubio Says
item.description: President Donald Trump thinks Russia will likely walk away from Ukraine peace talks if the US threatens more sanctions, according to his top diplomat, supporting the White House’s decision not to pressure Moscow despite its resistance to a ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican from Florida and US secretary of state nominee for US President-elect Donald Trump, during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. The top Republican and Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee joined in praising Rubio at the Florida senator's nomination hearing for secretary of state, signaling he'll face one of the easiest confirmations of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet.

item.title: Trump Says Golden Dome System Will Be Operational in Three Years
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed that a “Golden Dome” missile-defense shield should be “fully operational” by the end of his term, saying it would be able to protect the US from threats including ballistic missiles, hypersonics and advanced cruise missiles.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 12: White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles looks on from behind a chart on the Golden Dome missile defense system as U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during a press conference in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on May 12, 2025, in Washington, DC. During the event, President Trump signed an executive order aimed at reducing the cost of prescription drugs and pharmaceuticals by 30% to 80%. (Photo by Andrew Harnik/Getty Images)

item.title: Venezuela Frees American as Chevron Waiver Is Set to Be Extended
item.description: Venezuela released an American citizen on the same day the US was set to give Chevron Corp. another 60-day waiver to operate in the country, part of a push by President Nicolas Maduro’s government and some voices in the Trump administration to improve ties.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Zerpa, Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: A pump jack stands near an oil spill at a Petroleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) facility in the Orinoco Belt of El Tigre, Venezuela, on Friday, Oct. 12, 2018. State-owned PDVSA doesn't publish statistics, but environmentalists and analysts keep seemingly endless lists of examples of wayward crude - unleashed by busted valves, ripped gaskets, and cracked pipes - that they say has polluted waterways and farmland and probably has seeped into the nation's aquifers. Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Loses Patience With SALT Demand as Tax Bill Faces Snag
item.description: President Donald Trump is growing frustrated with demands to significantly boost the cap on the state and local tax deduction, according to a senior administration official, signaling a deadlock as Republicans aim to quickly pass a giant tax-cut bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Catherine Lucey, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Promised Record Deportations. How’s That Going?
item.description: President Donald Trump has vowed to carry out the largest deportation campaign in US history, a promise that mirrors one he made but failed to fulfill during his first term. This time, Trump has shown greater determination.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents detain a suspect during a multi-agency targeted enforcement operation in Lyons, Illinois, US, on Sunday, Jan. 26, 2025. President Donald Trump has pledged to carry out the largest deportation effort in US history, vowing to ultimately deport all of the foreigners living in the country without permission. Photographer: Christopher Dilts/Bloomberg

item.title: Dutch Government Needs to Spend Up to €19 Billion More to Meet NATO Target
item.description: The Netherlands estimates it will need to boost defense spending by as much as €19 billion ($21.4 billion) a year to meet the expected new target for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Sarah Jacob

media:content.media:description: Netherland's Minister of Defense Ruben Brekelmans gives a statement as he arrives the annual Joint Expeditionary Force (JEF) Leaders' Summit in Oslo on May 9, 2025. From May 8-9, Norway hosts this year's summit for the members of the JEF coalition: UK, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Sweden and Norway. Their meeting will focus on the situation in Europe and regional cooperation on security challenges. (Photo by Terje Pedersen / NTB / AFP) / Norway OUT (Photo by TERJE PEDERSEN/NTB/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Hegseth Starts Fresh Probe Into ‘Disastrous’ Afghanistan Pullout
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced a new probe into the 2021 Afghanistan withdrawal, vowing accountability for what he called the Biden administration’s “disastrous and embarrassing” handling of the events that led to the deaths of 13 US troops.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth in the Rose Garden of the White House on May 1.

item.title: European Officials Step Up Pressure on Israel Over Gaza War
item.description: European and UK officials ratcheted up pressure on Israel over its latest offensive in Gaza, expanding the international outcry over the humanitarian crisis caused by the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Israeli military vehicles at Israel's southern border with the Gaza Strip on May 20.

item.title: EU Removes All Remaining Economic Sanctions Against Syria
item.description: The European Union has lifted all remaining economic sanctions against Syria, the bloc’s top diplomat Kaja Kallas told reporters after foreign ministers gathered in Brussels on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Stalls selling flags in Damascus. Photographer: Louai Beshara/Getty Images

item.title: Listen: Bloomberg’s Elon Musk Interview In-Full
item.description: Today on the Big Take: Editor at large for Bloomberg Weekend Mishal Husain interviews Elon Musk at the Qatar Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: David Gura, Naomi Shavin

media:content.media:description: Elon MusK, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., speaks via video link at the Qatar Economic Forum (QEF) in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. The fifth annual Qatar Economic Forum will gather government and business leaders in Doha to discuss what’s driving the global economy.

item.title: Trump Won’t Participate in G-20 in South Africa, Rubio Says
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio suggested President Donald Trump wouldn’t join a meeting of Group of 20 leaders in South Africa later this year, saying the country has been “consistently unaligned” with US policy.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin, Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio attends a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on May 20.

item.title: UK Considers Reducing Cash Portion of £20,000 ISA Allowance
item.description: The UK government is planning to reduce the amount of cash savers can put in tax-free accounts in a bid to create a US culture of retail investing among British households, according to Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Emma Reynolds

item.title: EU Likely to Propose Quota to Ban Russia Gas Imports by End 2027
item.description: The European Union is likely to propose a quota as the mechanism to enforce a bloc-wide import ban on Russian gas by the end of 2027, which officials say should provide companies with a legal basis to terminate long-term purchase contracts.
item.dc:creator: Ewa Krukowska

media:content.media:description: Pipework stands at the second train liquefaction and purification facility during its official opening at the Yamal LNG plant, operated by Novatek PJSC, in Sabetta, Russia, on Thursday, Aug. 9, 2018. Novatek is one of the largest independent natural gas producers in Russia.

item.title: Brazil Finance Chief Pivots as Lula Lingers in the Limelight
item.description: Not long ago, Brazil’s finance chief was a rising star in the government of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Now, factors beyond Fernando Haddad’s control have put his political ambitions on hold.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Fernando Haddad

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: When Germany’s Angela Merkel was photographed at the 2018 Group of Seven meeting, surrounded by others and leaning over a cross-armed Donald Trump, the image was seen as a public display of world leaders pushing back against a disruptive US president.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Crypto Entrepreneur Sun Will Join Trump’s Memecoin Dinner
item.description: Crypto entrepreneur Justin Sun announced that he’s joining a high-profile dinner with the US President Donald Trump later this week.
item.dc:creator: Muyao Shen

media:content.media:description: Justin Sun, founder of Tron and chief executive officer of BitTorrent Inc., speaks during the TOKEN2049 in Singapore, on Wednesday, on Sept. 28, 2022. The cryptocurrency event runs through Sept. 29.

item.title: Trump Draws New Pope Into a Tricky Role on Russia’s War
item.description: Pope Leo XIV’s proposed role hosting Ukraine-Russia peace talks in the Vatican marks a significant development for the first US-born pontiff, just as the Trump administration appears to be stepping back from leading negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV

item.title: LA Mayor Signs Order Aiming to Boost Local Film, TV Production
item.description: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass signed an executive order aimed at revitalizing the local film and television industry by making it easier to obtain production permits — a task currently managed by a city- and county-backed office called FilmLA.
item.dc:creator: Maxwell Adler

media:content.media:description: Representative Karen Bass, a Democrat from California, introduces US President Joe Biden at Los Angeles Metro's Purple (D Line) Extension Transit Project in Los Angeles, California, US, on Thursday, Oct. 13, 2022. The $550 billion bipartisan infrastructure bill that was signed into law last year includes billions in investments for roads, rail, and ports, as Biden has touted the bill as a measure that will ease bottlenecks driving inflation over the long term.

item.title: Why South Africa’s Land Law Is at Heart of Trump Row
item.description: Land ownership remains an explosive issue in South Africa more than three decades after White-minority rule ended. It’s also at the center of a diplomatic row with the US, as President Donald Trump and his Pretoria-born billionaire ally Elon Musk falsely claim that the South African government is engaging in land grabs and that there’s a genocide against White Afrikaner farmers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa and Donald Trump Source: Bloomberg

item.title: EU Sanctions Ships That Helped Move Gas From Russia’s Yamal LNG
item.description: The European Union imposed sanctions on three vessels that helped move gas cargoes from Russia’s Yamal LNG project, further squeezing Moscow’s energy revenues.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: A gas flare, also known as a flare stack, burns at the Yamal LNG plant, operated by Novatek PJSC, in Sabetta, Russia, on Wednesday, Aug. 8, 2018. Novatek is one of the largest independent natural gas producers in Russia.

item.title: Spain to Host Arab-EU Summit on May 25 to Discuss Gaza War
item.description: Spain will host a meeting of foreign ministers from the European Union and the Arab world in Madrid on May 25 as it seeks to ramp up diplomatic pressure on Israel to halt its latest offensive in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: BRUSSELS, BELGIUM - MAY 20: José Manuel Albares Bueno, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Spain, speaks to the press at the European Council headquarters during the meeting of Foreign Affairs Ministers on May 20, 2025 in Brussels, Belgium. Today's EU's Foreign Affairs Council meeting includes a session with EU Defense Ministers to discuss military support for Ukraine. (Photo by Omar Havana/Getty Images)

item.title: US Charges Congresswoman With Assault, Drops Case Against Baraka
item.description: The US Justice Department charged a Democratic House lawmaker from Newark, New Jersey, with assault after a confrontation with US immigration officers, while dropping a trespassing charge against the mayor arising from the same incident.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Chris Strohm, Ellen M Gilmer

media:content.media:description: LaMonica McIver calls for the release of Newark Mayor Ras Baraka after his arrest while protesting outside an ICE detention facility in Newark on May 9.

item.title: UK Pauses Israel Trade Talks and Issues Sanctions Over Gaza
item.description: The UK announced a series of measures to punish Israel over its actions in Gaza, joining international efforts to ramp up pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: William Selway

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at London Gateway port. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
